Nanomaterials in Superlubricity
Wenzheng Zhai and Kun Zhou*
The vanishing friction, known as superlubricity, is potentially a significant performance indicator in the development of nanostructured materials and has become increasingly important for realizing energy saving and extending the life of mechanical components. Herein, a systematic review of recent progress in nanomaterials for achieving the superlubric state is provided, beginning with a brief introduction of nanostructured materials in superlubricity and its wide potential applications. Subsequently, a detailed discussion of experimental and simulation works on the different spatial structures of nanomaterials associated with size effects ranging from 0D to 3D nanostructures is given, with an emphasis on solid and liquid superlubricity. Finally, this work concludes with perspectives on the challenges and future directions for developing nanomaterials in the field of superlubricity.

However, structural deformation and defects existing in materials could suppress such superlubricity when their dimensions increase from the nanoscale to macroscale.[18–20] In addition, homogeneous rigid interfaces show frictional anisotropy relevant to their relative orientation, exhibiting a tendency to rotate from an ultralow frictional incommensurate state to an aligned commensurate configuration during sliding. This significant anisotropic nature of friction restrains further applications of superlubricity. Recently, an effective strategy based on the intrinsic lattice constant mismatch of contacting surfaces (single-crystalline gra-
phene/hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN)) was proposed by Song et al.[21] to achieve incommensurability. The robust superlubric state in microscale heterogeneous contact originated mainly from different internal degrees of freedom within contacting layers. They exhibited enhanced out-of-plane atomic undulation even in the aligned configuration, which could decay the orientation misalignment during rotation, thereby preserving a flat sliding surface. This reveals that a robust superlubric regime would be generally realized at both thin-layered material interfaces and other complex rigid contact. Nowadays, superlubricity has attracted extensive attention among researchers in critical aspects including solid superlubricity and liquid superlubricity. Solid superlubricity refers to the process or technique employed for achieving a superlubric state under dry friction. In contrast to solid superlubricity, liquid superlubricity involves reaching the superlubric state with the aid of a liquid medium.
One of the most momentous advances of liquid superlubricity is hydration lubrication, where a hydration layer with high pressure-supporting and rapid relaxing abilities is firmly kept by charges to provide an efficient fluid lubrication with low shear stress.[22–24] Hydration lubrication is a promising method for achieving superlow friction in aqueous media. Recent experiments realized macroscale superlubricity through hydration lubrication with the aid of Li+, Na+, and K+ ions at a high contact pressure of 250 MPa.[25] Hydration nanoshells were tenaciously held by these alkali metal ions they surround, supporting extremely high normal forces and having effective fluid lubrication simultaneously.
Over the last two decades, research efforts for superlubricity have been conducted on materials with heterogeneous nanostructures that could be controlled at the nanoscale in various dimensions. sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The frictional performance of materials, particularly their superlubricity behavior in which friction completely or nearly vanishes, have received increasing interest.[1–10] Superlubricity with a state of friction coefficient below 0.001, first proposed by Hirano and Shinjo,[11] has been considered to be one of the most effective ways to alleviate the negative effects of friction and wear. Reportedly, energy dissipation from friction accounts for one third of the fuel consumption in automobiles,[12] and wear also significantly reduces the lifetime of mechanical components. To date, superlubricity with exceptionally low energy dissipation has been realized at both the micro-[13] and macroscales[14] under low-[15] and high-pressure[13] conditions as well as in ultrahigh vacuum[16] and ambient environments.[17]
Superlubricity is normally pertinent to specific lubrication conditions, such as the incommensurate structural phase of two surfaces and the paradigm of hydration lubrication,

Figure 1 presents a set of statistical results of scientific articles published in 1990–2018, which were retrieved using the title(s) or topic(s) containing the keyword(s) of “superlubricity,” “superlow friction,” or ultralow friction” in the Institute of Scientific Information (ISI) database. Remarkably, an increasing number of relevant published papers indicates that superlubricity is becoming a new research focus with significant impacts.
Many reviews concerning nanomaterials have been conducted on their fabrication strategies,[26,27] applications,[28] electrochemical[29,30] and optical[31] properties, etc. Nevertheless, the progress of applying various nanomaterials in the critical field of superlubricity has not been systematically reviewed yet. A timely review would allow the scientific community to keep pace with rapid developments in this field, and offer promising solutions to overcome lubrication challenges for a variety of nanotechnologies including micro/nano-electromechanical systems (MEMS/ NEMS),[32] water transport control,[33] biomedical engineering,[34] atomic force microscopy (AFM),[35] aerospace and wind energy applications,[34] as well as other electronic devices,[36] for which maintaining their mechanical stability is pivotal, as shown in Figure 2. For example, conductive AFM is one of the most effective instruments to characterize electrical properties of materials at the nanoscale. However, a critical challenge associated with this characterization technique is the low reliability of AFM tips during high-current testing, which is related to rapid wear by the friction of tip-sample interfaces. Therefore, superlubricity at the tip-sample interfaces is a promising way to avoid tip wear for reliable nanoscaled electrical characterization.

sections.heading: 2. 0D Nanomaterials
sections.text: 0D nanomaterials have been well-studied worldwide with regards to their fabrication techniques,[37–39] shape control methods,[40] and size-dependent properties.[41] They have been applied in various MEMS and NEMS subjected to oscillating, rotating or sliding contact,[42–46] where a significant reduction of stiction, friction, and wear is desirable.

sections.heading: 2.1. Solid Superlubricity
sections.text:
Solid superlubricity of a single 0D nanoparticle shows obvious load-dependent anisotropy. Itamura et al.[47] studied frictional behaviors of a C60 molecular bearing system (graphite/ C60/graphite interfaces) at the atomic scale by molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. An ultralow friction property with directional dependences was observed, which was originated from the remarkable directional dependence between

Figure 3a shows a schematic diagram of the C60-based bearing configuration illustrating an intermediate C60 particle (marked in red) sandwiched by two graphene nanosheets (green). The dotted parallelogram refers to a 1 × 1 unit cell in the configuration. The lateral position L of the top nanosheet is changed along the scanning direction with angles ranging from −30° to 90°. The original orientation between the top and bottom nanosheets was fitted as AA-stacking. The average lateral force FL reached a peak value within a narrow region approximately in the [1010] direction (corresponding to the scan angle of 30°), while in the [1230] direction (the scan angle of 0°), FL showed a minimum value of nearly zero, as shown in Figure 3b. The C60 bearing system exhibited superlubricity at a low-loading condition originating
from the incommensurate configuration between contact surfaces. However, at high-loading contact, superlubricity would be affected by collective impacts of the tip effect, deformation of nanosheets and shift of the nanosheet around the [0001] direction,[48] leading to the commensurate configuration with a high FL between the C60 bearing and top graphene interface in the [1010] direction.
However, superlubricity of multiple nanoparticles shows dependence on the volume content rather than on directionality. With an appropriate concentration of 3.6% ionic liquid (IL)-modified carbon quantum dot (CQD) nanoparticles, a superlow friction of ≈0.006 was found, which was considerably lower than other IL-modified CQD contents (concentrations of 0%, 0.98%, and 8.2%).[49] The superlow friction performance is believed to relate to the sphere-in-shell architecture of the IL-modified CQD nanoparticles, but correlative lubricating mechanisms need to be further explored. Figure 4a schematically illustrates the assembling process of initially randomly distributed ILs into an ordered distribution of ILs on the surface of CQDs, which was caused by the interaction of CQDs with ILs driven by the high density of polar-functional groups in ILs and high specific surface areas of CQDs. Ultimately, a sphere-in-shell structure can be formed owing to charge and shape effects. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) characterizations indicated that the as-prepared nanomaterials with excellent dispersibility have graphite nanocrystal structures with an average diameter of 5.6 nm, as shown in Figure 4b–d. Tribological experiments demonstrated that such nanoparticles with a CQD content of 3.6 vol% exhibited a superlow friction coefficient of ≈0.006. Frictional behaviors of these nanoparticles depended on the volume content at the given condition ranging from 0.98 to 8.2 vol%. The friction coefficient reached up to ≈0.05 as the CQD content was increased to 8.2 vol%.
A rational manipulation of 0D nanomaterials for realizing superlubricity requires the consideration of their directionality and volume content as well as loading conditions. In addition, contact size has been demonstrated to be a critical factor that should be considered for achieving superlubricity, as the

threshold of contact size for a commensurate-incommensurate transition primarily relates to mutual effects of interaction energies of contact surfaces and compliance of lateral contact stiffness.[50–54]
Recently, Dietzel et al.[55] provided experimental evidence for such a threshold of the contact size from testing the frictional force of Sb nanoparticles on the MoS2 substrate. A superlubric regime exhibiting a monotonic reduction of shear stress with progressively decreasing contact size prevails in fine nanoparticles below 15 000 nm2. By contrast, coarse particles showed a transition whereby the shear stress converges toward a constant value. In comparison with the MoS2 substrate, the highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) substrate for Sb particles showed superlubric states over the full range of contact size (Figure 5a). Figure 5b illustrates the calculated energy fluctuations (the top panel) and force variations (the bottom panel) of x-/y-equivalent applied stress on a Sb particle for Sb/ MoS2 and Sb/HOPG nanocontact simulations, respectively. The center panel presents the charge redistribution caused by nanoscale contact. The Sb/MoS2 configuration possesses a higher chemical-interaction energy than Sb/HOPG, which can cause different frictional properties and thresholds of the critical contact size. Such limitations need to be considered for designing the superlow friction contact regime in respect of 0D nanomaterials in superlubricity.
Besides Sb nanoparticles, nanodiamond particles were also selected to explicate the effect of contact size on superlubricity between incommensurate sliding interfaces through MD simulations.[57] The larger contact size (814.3 Å2) was prone to exhibit an ultralow friction force. Superlubricity was found to
break down for small contact sizes (114.5–203.6 Å2) caused by a transformation from the incommensurate contact state to the commensurate contact state at the interface.
Thus far, superlubric states have been realized and wellstudied at the nanoscale. However, incommensurate contact for superlubricity is susceptible to losses during expansion to the macroscale due to structural deformation of materials.[14] Nevertheless, a good manipulation of 0D-nanostructured materials presents an attractive pathway to the solution of challenges arising from the scaling effect for robust superlubricity. Berman et al.[12] first obtained fairly stable superlubric states at the macroscale by applying graphene nanoflakes with nanodiamond particles on the surface of diamond-like carbon (DLC) coatings. Macroscopic superlubricity originated from the formation of novel 0D nanoscroll structures, which promoted a reduction of contact area and incommensurability between the DLC coating and nanoscrolls during the sliding process. MD simulation results and experimental analyses demonstrated that the 3D nanostructures consisted of nanodiamonds wrapped by graphene nanoscrolls, as presented in Figure 6a,b. In addition, nanodiamonds played a critical role in the formation of stable graphene nanoscrolls under the dry sliding frictional condition, leading to robust superlubricity (friction coefficient of ≈0.005, Figure 6c).
Recently, an architecture of onion-like carbon obtained from the tribochemical reaction of a hydrogenated DLC surface sliding against MoS2 nanolayers with nanodiamonds was found to show macroscale superlubricity at the dry nitrogen condition.[10] Detailed MD simulation (Figure 7a–h) and experimental (Figure 7i–l) investigations indicated that under high

Such structure formation mechanisms are depicted in Figure 7. MoS2 patches with a high elastic bending modulus started to form nanoscrolls around nanodiamonds between sliding surfaces. As the frictional process proceeded, MoS2 disintegrated into molybdenum and sulfur under the high contact stress (≈0.2 GPa). The sulfur part was likely to bond to the oxygenated nanodiamond surface as a result of the high affinity of sulfur toward oxygen, resulting in the transformation from the sp3 bond of nanodiamonds into the sp2 carbon bond, and eventually into graphitic nanolayers in the form of onion-like carbon structure. This structural transformation between contacting surfaces led to reduced contact areas with incommensurate contact, hence yielding the superlubric state.
These results provide convincing observations of superlubric failure in terms of contact size and scaling effects of 0D nanomaterials at both the nano- and macroscopic scales. Interestingly, the macroscopic contact interface consisting of a large number of nanoscale contact areas is insensitive to the loading effect during frictional sliding, which is essential for engineering applications.

sections.heading: 2.2. Liquid Superlubricity
sections.text:
For liquid superlubricity, the superlow friction coefficient is related to multiple effects including that of smooth contacting
interfaces, low viscosities as well as minimum shear resistances, and can be influenced by the content of nanoparticles in a liquid solution, relative humidity, contact loads, and type of relative motion.
A significantly improved boundary lubrication behavior for DLC films sliding against a Si3N4 ball was observed from adding 1.0 wt% boron nitride nanoparticles in the poly-α-olefin lubricant oil.[58] Boron nitride additives acted as nanoscale ball bearings for contacting surfaces at the 10 N loading condition. In the meantime, the weak bonding of additives debilitated the interactions between contacting interfaces due to reduced van der Waals forces, thus improving the lubricating behavior at the Si3N4/DLC interface. Consequently, superlubricity could be achieved with the addition of 1.0 wt% nanoparticles for the boundary lubrication. However, the superlubric transition was not observed in cases of adding 0.5 and 2.0 wt% nanoparticles, implying that the additive content bears a significant effect.
Chen et al.[59] found that both the nanodiamond glycerol colloidal solution and glycerol solution can act as a lubricant with a stable superlubric state for the steel/steel interface at 40% RH humidity, while the lubricant modified by nanodiamonds demonstrated lower wear than the glycerol solution. Superlubricity was the result of hydrodynamic effects with the formation of a hydrogen bonding film. Such hydrodynamic films prevent direct contact between opposite asperities as well as contact among asperities and nanodiamonds, promoting the achievement of an ultralow friction coefficient, as shown in Figure 8a. Tortora and Veeregowda[60] compared tribological properties of 0.1 wt% nanodiamonds-modified aqueous glycerol through rotary and reciprocation testing methods. Superlubricity can only be obtained at the rotary mode in the aqueous glycerol lubricant, following the formation of a thick lubricating film consisting of free water molecules supported by aqueous glycerol. However, the reciprocation mode triggered significantly higher friction because the lubricating film collapsed under repetitive stress during reciprocation-induced boundary lubrication. For the rotary mode, nanodiamond particles accumulated at the contact zone and played the role in micropolishing the smooth surface, thus contributing to the decrease of friction.
These studies enrich current research progress on liquid superlubricity by involving 0D nanoparticles, thereby opening
up further possibilities for exploring novel liquid lubrication systems with a superlubric potential by controlling the content of nanoparticles, relative humidity, contact loads, and type of relative motion.

Lately, significant progress of macroscale superlubricity in 1D nanomaterials was achieved from perfect centimeterslong triple-walled CNTs.[66] The well-structured CNTs enabled macroscale superlubricity under ambient conditions. Zhang et al.[17] first observed macroscale superlubricity in perfect double-walled CNTs by a nanomanipulator-loaded scanning electron microscope. Figure 9 shows schematic illustrations and TEM observations of pulling out a CNT inner shell from a double-walled CNT. The CNT experienced stable friction below 1 nN throughout the entire pulling process. The dissipation energy for this pull-out process was 0.218 J m−2, and was independent of the CNT length, as shown in Figure 10a,b. Additionally, the dissipation energy was significantly reduced compared with previously reported experimental observations of 0.450–0.670 J m−2.[67] Such low energy was attributed to the effects of van der Waals forces which dominated interaction mechanisms between the inner and outer layers of CNTs.[68,69] For a given perfect double-walled CNT, two types of the van der Waals forces have been illustrated in Figure 10c, namely the overlapped type (type I) with negligible shear stress because of offsets in the van der Waals forces among contiguous atoms of inner and outer layers, and the edge type (type II) which depends on the external size of the CNT.[17,70]
Theoretically, for CNTs with perfect structures, changes in the van der Waals forces mainly depend on the specific size of the pulled out layer. Note that, besides incommensurate
contact, the perfect structure without defects in CNTs also has a significant effect on achieving persistent and stable macroscale superlubric state, as defects can provide energetically favorable reconstructions of the inner or outer graphene layer which normally causes additional energy consumption and the consequent increase of friction.
Importantly, the interwall friction of double-walled CNTs shows a linear correlation with the pulling velocity of the inner shell.[71] Figure 11a illustrates the process of towing out an inner shell from the double-walled CNT with surface modification by TiO2 nanoparticles, demonstrating velocity-correlated friction among inter shells of CNTs (Figure 11b), which was attributed to the Stokes-like viscous drag effect. Inter shell friction of curved CNTs was much higher than that of straight CNTs, indicating a remarkable impact of axial curvature on inter shell friction (Figure 11c). Large axial curvature could lead to a sharp increase of inter shell friction, resulting in increased friction during pull-out of the shell from CNTs. Thus, CNTs with larger axial curvature tended to be broken under large shear deformation.
MD simulation results offer further insights for revealing mechanisms of the superlubric state in the edge-driven system over different length scales. The specific transition from a superlubric state to a high-frictional regime would occur at slider lengths above a critical size.[72] Based on a practical example of incommensurate double-walled CNTs, the critical length was estimated to be 0.5 m which had been verified to a certain extent by previous experimental observations, where the maximum length of CNTs showing superlubric behavior was found to be below this critical value.[17] For different tribological systems, further experiments and simulations are required to obtain enough data on the critical lengths of 1D nanostructures for greater control of their superlubric behavior.

Superlubricity-related hydrodynamic slippage at the carbonwater interface inside CNTs can be quantitatively determined as a function of nanotube radius R. Results from MD simulations revealed the slippage lengths of 30–105 nm in CNTs with R ranging from 0.83 to 2.495 nm relevant to the curvature-dependent friction mechanism.[81] However, the slippage lengths numerically predicted were lower than those from experimental observations. The experimental data showed the radius-dependent slippage length reaching up to 300 nm in the CNT,[82] indicating that the MD simulations might miscalculate the quantitative interfacial dynamics resulted from the uncontrollable slippage length.[81,83] In addition, the flow velocities of water transport in CNTs realized by the MD simulations
normally far exceeded those by experiments,[75–80] further limiting the exploration of the underlying mechanisms.
Noteworthily, a recent study reported that the flow velocities carried out by the MD simulation could be achieved of the same order of magnitude as experimental ones.[84] Phonon-induced oscillations of the friction force at the carbon-water interface was observed, leading to the enhancement in diffusion coefficients of confined water above 300%. However, different flow behaviors of water molecules were demonstrated between CNTs and boron nitride nanotubes (BNNTs) despite their same crystallography (Figure 12). No obvious slip of water was observed in BNNTs with the radii R of 23 and 26 nm, which was ascribed to their insulating property. Further systematic explorations need to be carried out for investigating the effects of surface defects on the superlow friction behavior at the carbon-water interface. This will help to extend this superlubric technique to more effective water filtration applications.
4. 2D Nanomaterials
Recently, 2D materials including transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) and graphene have received particular attention for their demonstrated potential in superlubricity.[85–88] This section summarizes recent progress in research on solid and liquid superlubricity of 2D nanomaterials.
4.1. Solid Superlubricity
Hexagonal molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) has become a hot TMD material with a lamellar structure. It is held by weak interactions between MoS2 monolayers, which readily provide relative slippage ability,[89,90]
making MoS2 a promising solid lubricant to the friction reduction of contact interfaces.[91–96] A simulation study by Onodera et al.[97] revealed that two MoS2 single layers with incommensurate contact exhibited superlow friction caused by an elimination of atomic forces along the sliding direction; however, with commensurate contact, friction of the contact layers increased significantly, which was one hundred times higher than that of incommensurate contact. Accurate experimental characterizations of frictional properties of a MoS2 single layer have not been realized until 2017 when Li et al.[87] developed a versatile method using an in situ scanning electron microscope equipped with a silicon nanowire force tester, which can be applied for quantitatively measuring frictional behaviors of a single layer of laminated materials. Besides TMD materials, a nanoscaled graphene flake attached to the AFM tip was developed to explore structural
superlubricity during sliding over a graphite substrate.[98] Even at environmental conditions, a renewable superlubric state was observed in the simulations of the sliding graphene flake with high speeds, which was related to a high friction transient during the rapid rotation of the graphene flake along crystallographic graphite arrangements.[99] The high-speed motion of the nanoflake on graphite was predominated by friction scattering, which was basically a 2D system that could be restrained from restricting the nanoflake with quasi-1D frictional waveguide or from extending the substrate to activate a lattice mismatch. Figure 13a,b shows the velocity component (vx) of the nanoflake and bonding energies of the van der Waals forces (EvdW) between the graphene nanoflake and the graphite substrate, respectively, indicating obvious oscillations near the alignment with the rotation angle (∆θc) of 1.4°. Figure 13c illustrates eight snapshots of the nanoflake supported by the substrate at various positions identified in Figure 13a,b. During rotational misalignment of the nanoflake, a small unit cell size (am) was observed
on the pattern, which could be regarded as the primary cause of incommensurate lattices for the superlubric state. Figure 13d–g shows variations of a corrugation potential specified as EvdW energies between the nanoflake and substrate. At the positions near the alignment (see snapshots 5 and 6), the corrugation potentials were two orders of magnitude larger than those at the superlubric state. In addition, the atomistic MD simulations revealed that graphene nanoflakes showed lower friction than perfect graphene as a result of the reduced potential energy barrier by low coverage, and the collective mechanism of independently moving flakes that slipped at different times within one period.[100]
In addition to the graphite substrate, metallic substrates such as Ni and Au have been demonstrated to have great potentials to achieve superlubricity with graphene. The superlubric state was observed by inserting monolayer graphene at interfaces of pseudomorphic Ni (111), which originated from the interactions between graphene-π and Ni-3d orbitals.[101] Firstprinciples calculations revealed that monolayer graphene could screen the intense attractive force of the interface, leading to an obvious decrease in sliding friction and adhesive forces. On inserting the second monolayer, the two single layers were found to attach on each metal surface, resulting in further reduced adhesion. The corrugation strength and adhesion continued to decrease by inserting the third monolayer, consequently reaching a constant value as more graphene layers were introduced. This strategy provides a promising approach to achieve the superlubric state similar to loading graphene nanoflakes at the sliding or rolling interface.
By sliding against an Au (111) substrate through the classical MD simulation technique, the static frictional behavior of graphene nanoribbons (GNRs) was analyzed at the atomic scale to explore their intrinsic structural superlubric behavior.[102] Static

Compared with the pure graphene interface, the graphene/h-BN heterojunction can stabilize the superlubric state by reducing the pinning effect from the edge atoms at the higher loading conditions, indicating the potential of applying 2D nanomaterial heterojunctions for obtaining a stable solid superlubric state at the graphene/ceramic interface. Superlubricity originated from the gradual emergence of Moiré patterns, as shown in Figure 15, which could result in an integrated stick-slip motion turning to smooth sliding similar to a soliton.[104]
Such heterojunctions show the potential in prohibiting the formation of commensurate contact and reducing the edge pinning effect. The graphene/MoS2 heterostructure showed an obvious reduction of the interlayer lateral stress by twoorders of magnitude when compared to the homogeneous graphene/graphene or MoS2/MoS2 layered structure, demonstrating the promising architecture to obtain the solid superlubric state.
Although theory-based simulation and calculation works have indicated that the incommensurate configurations of graphene could be tuned toward the superlubric state,[88,101–108] superlubricity of graphene was basically observed in a few experimental works,[12,109–111] because critical incommensurate contact for the superlubric regime was vulnerable to failure from introducing defects and suffering local deformation. The defect-controlled frictional mechanism of graphene revealed that the introduction of vacancies played a crucial role in determining the friction behaviors of oxidized graphene.[112] The vacancies reinforced the out-of-plane deformation flexibility of graphene, yielding strong wrinkling in graphene nanosheets at the contact interface with the corresponding increased contact area and frictional force.
Sliding and rotating behaviors of graphene nanoflakes against the graphene substrate were explored by Feng et al.[108] via a scanning tunneling microscope (STM). They found that a graphene nanoflake initially shifted via commensurate contact to incommensurate contact with a subsequent transient shifting to another commensurate contact, as shown in Figure 17a. Further information regarding displacements of the graphene nanoflake are illustrated in Figure 17b–e. Three graphene nanoflakes first appeared in the field of view (Figure 17b). After sequential STM scanning along this area, the fourth nanoflake was identified in the view denoted by a yellow arrow, followed by a consequent shift to the left direction (Figure 17c,d), before ending up at the position with the rotation of 60° (Figure 17e). Such movement originated from the van der Waals forces between the tip of the STM and the nanoflake, resulting in the slip motion to the incommensurate contact position. It was also found that the average shift displacement of the nanoflakes was higher at the operating temperature of 5 K than at 77 K, implying the thermal-fluctuation-triggered transition from incommensurate contact to commensurate contact.
Generally, a good achieving of stable superlubricity in 2D nanomaterials requires an emphasis on the realization of sustained incommensurate sliding contact. However, it is still a challenging task for the design of superlubric states under high contact stress or operating strain conditions, in different atmospheres, as well as at facultative rotating angles (sliding directions) between interlayers, limiting their further practical applications.[13] To address this challenge, Liu et al.[13] employed the chemical vapor deposition (CVD) technique of free metallic catalysts to prepare the graphene-coated SiO2 sphere probe, as presented in Figure 18. Based on this nano-layered structure, a stable superlow friction coefficient of ≈0.003 was obtained at the graphene/graphene interface under the high contact stress of 1 GPa and at a random sliding direction between the sphere surface and the substrate surface. The superlubric state resulted from multicontact between the spherical asperities and the graphene nanograins with random orientations, which impeded the formation of integral commensurate contact and the synchronous slip process. This technique of designing 3D nanostructures for superlubricity can be promisingly extended to other 2D nanomaterials involving monolayer MoS2 and WS2 covering the sphere tip.

sections.heading: 4.2. Liquid Superlubricity
sections.text:
In contrast to solid superlubricity of 2D nanomaterials, liquid superlubricity has only been achieved in carbon based films at present. DLC, which is a well-known metastable type of amorphous carbon having a fraction of sp3 bonding, has widespread tribological applications in the areas of magnetic storage devices, engine components, biocoating, as well as MEMS and NEMS.[113–123]
Superlubricity of flat tetrahedral amorphous carbon (ta-C) has been realized in engineering films for bearing steels at the oleic acid lubricating condition.[124] The macroscale superlow friction regime (<0.01) of moving components coated with ta-C was ascribed to the partial oxidization of graphene-like nanoflakes, leading to the formation of a tribofilm with the thickness

The formation of the tribofilm, which was suitable for superlubricity in fluid lubrication, can be explained by the following features. First, at the running-in stage, the upper surface of the ta-C coating was dominated by sp2 carbon under high shear stress (Figure 19a), because lubricant oils can facilitate the tribochemical reaction during the frictional process, resulting in the remarkable structural transformations in ta-C from an initially high content of sp3 to sp2 planar carbon. Second, when the sp2 carbon content increased to a certain threshold (≈60% based on the simulation result in Figure 19b), the 2D carbon bonding would be prone to be present on the surface of contacting asperities (Figure 19c). Third, the graphene-like structures could be partially oxidized by decomposing the oleic acid (Figure 19d). Such mechanisms of the graphene-like structural transformations during the sliding processes provide further possibilities in the design of novel structures linking the atomic simulation behaviors with the macroscale experimental observations of the superlubric states of the ta-C/oleic acid lubrication system.

sections.heading: 5. 3D Nanomaterials
sections.text:
A good design for the materials with 3D nanostructures is becoming increasingly important given the need for advanced functional applications in biomedical engineering, water
transport, energy conversion and storage, molecular separation, sensors, and nanoreactors,[125–133] in which an efficient friction reduction is critical for operational stability and reliability.[134–137] This section focuses on the examples of 3D nanomaterials with well-controlled architectures and their resultant superlubricity.
A recent study by Shi et al. reported the outstanding lubricity of C60 between GO-based nanolayers at the broad strain levels of 0–62%.[138] A novel ternary nanocomposite consisting of 0D fullerene, 1D silver nanowire and 2D graphene oxide was developed for high strain sensors with the desired strain range of >50%. During stretching, fullerene-induced interlayer slipping could accommodate local tensile stress to facilitate the strain (Figure 20), while crack initiation and growth in the ternary nanocomposite could sensitively change the electrical resistance over the entire working strain levels. This work provided strong prospects for the design of novel 3D nanostructures that could offer the desired superlubric states at large strain for practical strain sensors.
3D nanomaterials offer potentials for the realization of superlubricity in the engineering applications requiring high normal loads. Hierarchically structured graphitic-like amorphous carbon/MoS2 coatings with the thickness of ≈243 nm were fabricated by magnetron sputtering and pulse current plasma CVD techniques at 600 °C (Figure 21a).[85] At the 10 N normal load, the coatings showed the friction coefficient as low as 0.004 with high wear resistance (Figure 21b,c).

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions and Outlooks
sections.text:
The development of nanomaterials in stable superlubricity is particularly critical for energy conservation. This review provides recent achievements in the use of nanostructured materials with different dimensionality from 0D to 3D for the design of this superlubric state, and highlights the typical operating environments for superlubricity including the solid and liquid lubrication conditions. An explosive progress of superlubricity has been achieved in nanomaterials. 0D nanomaterials including C60, carbon quantum dots, Sb nanoparticles, nanodiamonds, nanoscrolls and onion-like carbon effectively promote the superlubric state due to their size effects that can result in the transition from commensurate contact to incommensurate contact within the local interface. In addition, representative studies have demonstrated successful superlubric regimes across the weak van der Waals interaction between two
contact surfaces through the addition of the 0D nanomaterials. CNTs have proven to be one effective type of 1D nanomaterials for enhanced superlow friction at both the nanoscale and the macroscale. With large internal stiffness from CC bonding and low interfacial stiffness caused by weak interplane interactions, these 1D carbon-based nanostructures would be good candidates for the implementation of practical superlubric applications. In addition, hydration lubrication in CNTs has revealed to be an effective way to realize ultralow friction for water transport applications.
The intrinsic lubricating property of 2D nanomaterials including graphene nanoflakes, MoS2, and graphene-based heterostructures enabled them of desired low-friction behaviors, but was highly susceptible to the change in the substrates. For MoS2, which is characterized by layers with strong chemical bonding and combined by relatively weak van der Waals forces, superlubricity could be ascribed to frictional anisotropy within

Among graphene and its 2D-nanostructured functional derivatives, both simulation and experimental works indicated a better antifriction performance of the graphene nanoflakes. The development of novel 3D-nanostructured materials including C60-modified GO films and graphitic-like amorphous carbon/ MoS2 composite coatings opened up a new path to the design
of nanostructures with superlubricity at high stress and strain levels.
Stimulated by the requirement of longterm device operations in a wide range of nanotechnological applications, numerous research works on the superlow behaviors of nanomaterials potentially applied in these areas have been carried out. Table 1 summarizes typical superlubric behaviors of the four cases at specific working conditions in which dimensionally different nanostructured materials are applied for lubricating objectives, providing preliminary guidelines for the selection of suitable nanomaterials with enhanced antifriction properties. It can be inferred that 0D nanomaterials hold a promising potential for superlubricity over a wide loading range. Carbon-based nanostructured materials and their hybrids can be considered as desirable 1D and 3D nanomaterials to the aim of the superlubric state. For 2D nano - materials, MoS2 and graphene nanoflakes seem to be desired candidates for robust superlubric states at the nanoscale and macroscale, respectively. Besides, the frictional behaviors of graphene nanoflakes are revealed to be superior to those of perfect graphene.
Nanomaterials that can provide sliding interfaces with strong normal-load-
supporting and weak shear-stress-resisting performance are desirable for superlubricity because systems with superlow friction both in solid and liquid superlubricity demonstrate such characteristics. Nanomaterials with heterogeneous structures and anticontamination surfaces are also promising; in these nanomaterials the lattice misfit of heterogeneous contact of the contamination-free interface can result in incommensurate positions of edge atoms, which can prevent the edge pinning effect during sliding contact, thus significantly reducing edge friction. Among the studied nanomaterials in superlubricity, 2D nanomaterials provide additional possibilities for superlubricity and related practical applications. This is because the high intralayer strength and low interlayer bonding energy of 2D nanomaterials match structural effects required for superlubricity, and the layered structure hinders surface contamination by limiting chemical reactivity with surroundings. Noteworthily, experimental observations have demonstrated that nanomaterials provide promising solutions to overcome the challenges in realizing superlubricity at the macroscale. Of particular interest is the structural effects of 2D nanomaterials that may extend the shear length range to the macroscale. Furthermore, integration of 0D and 2D nanostructure elements is an efficient strategy to explore the full potential of these two complementary counterparts, which would provide extra mechanical strength and nano-ball-bearing effects during the sliding process of practical applications.
Remarkable progress of nanomaterials in the field of superlubricity also brings new challenges in both solid and liquid superlubricity. A good development of novel nanomaterials presents intriguing prospects for solid superlubricity. In addition

Specifically, the C120-like molecular structure has been reported to be the best candidate for the exploration of the lowest-energy structure.[141] Meanwhile, h-BN has been predicted to achieve superlubricity through a registry index model. However, the friction performance of these nanomaterials is yet to be experimentally confirmed. Important tasks are the identification of effective characterization techniques and the development of experimental configurations to correlate theoretical simulation works with real experimental observations for high-order fullerenes and h-BN. Also, the exploration of hybrid-layered nanostructures such as graphene on h-BN[101] and complex-layered metal dichalcogenides is required to obtain the superlubric state with underlying microstructural mechanisms.
Considering that deformation-induced defects which act as alignment positions for commensurate contact can lead to a breakdown of superlubricity, it is valuable to explore superlubric contact of amorphous nanomaterials which show distinct deformation mechanisms and higher stiffness compared with their crystalline counterparts. Incommensurate
contact between amorphous clusters and graphite shows a contacting-area-dependent friction force which is proportional to the square root of the area, implying potentials in extending incommensurability to the macroscale in terms of rigid surfaces. As superlubricity of amorphous structures has been preliminarily confirmed, further fundamental studies into the sliding friction of the amorphous material pairs need to be carried out by simulation and experimental works. In addition, conventional experimental data for superlubricity were obtained under relatively low loading and speed conditions, which are different from those applied in practical systems where higher loading and speed conditions normally result in deformation of the contact surface. In this regard, elaborate experiments on obtaining of superlubric state require integration of the rigid amorphous materials with severe loading and high-speed sliding conditions.
For the case of liquid superlubricity, ultrasmooth contact interfaces and low viscosities of lubricants have been demonstrated to be critical to the achievement of the superlubric state. However, the realization of superlubricity at the macroscale in engineering applications calls for the balance of the

Also, low viscosities required for superlubricity affect the load-bearing capacity of lubricants which is of key importance in practical engineering applications. An appropriate application of nanomaterials as additives in lubricants presents feasibility toward overcoming these challenges, as their polishing and

This makes them of great potentials to bridge the gap between the conditions required for designed superlubricity and practical applications. In summary, superlubricity serves as one of the most promising properties of functional nanomaterials for energy saving applications.

metadata.abstractText: The vanishing friction, known as superlubricity, is potentially a significant performance indicator in the development of nanostructured materials and has become increasingly important for realizing energy saving and extending the life of mechanical components. Herein, a systematic review of recent progress in nanomaterials for achieving the superlubric state is provided, beginning with a brief introduction of nanostructured materials in superlubricity and its wide potential applications. Subsequently, a detailed discussion of experimental and simulation works on the different spatial structures of nanomaterials associated with size effects ranging from 0D to 3D nanostructures is given, with an emphasis on solid and liquid superlubricity. Finally, this work concludes with perspectives on the challenges and future directions for developing nanomaterials in the field of superlubricity.
